results.title: Morality: the process of moral development (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Marcus Krigbaum, Davidson Films, Eclipse Films (US) and Roy Anthony Cox
results.brief_description: Dr Susan Merrsemen-Warren and Dr Elliot Turiel interview and test children from the age of four until early adulthood in order to examine their concepts of sharing, fairness, justice, and other attitudes linked to the process of moral development.

results.title: Moral judgement and reasoning (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Examines various concepts of moral development as postulated by Freud, Piaget and Kohlberg and points out that moral knowledge comes to a child from many sources, including parents, older siblings and playmates.

results.title: Moral development (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Developmental psychology today”.
Examines two opposing theories of moral development, that of Lawrence Kohlberg who believes that there are stages of moral development tied to cognitive development, and that of the learning theorists who contend that moral behaviour like all behaviour is learned, and that reasons for actions are irrelevant. Using Dr Stanley Milgrim’s famous obedience experiment each of the six stages of moral reasoning is represented in this film, one at a time, by six different participants. The stages differ in the types of reasons a person gives for making a decision about a moral dilemma and in the type of concern the person shows for the self, society, and authority.

results.title: Mopokes in action
results.brief_description: A scout training film showing the patrol system at work. The activities of a patrol, “The Mopokes”, including a weekly patrol meeting, a patrol outing and a patrol camp. The broadening of the patrol leader’s outlook is shown by his trip to a jamboree and his ability to help his patrol by virtue of having gained his 1st Class badge. How the patrol system offers the Scoutmaster the opportunity of developing leadership in boys.

results.title: Mooti: child of New India
results.creator_credit: Atlantis Productions and J. Michael Hagopian
results.brief_description: The story of a Hindu village boy who plays a part in a changing India. Through Mooti’s eyes are presented the three major concepts of the film: change to new tools, change to new industries, change to new relationships.

results.title: Moonwalk
results.creator_credit: Peretz Johnnes, Learning Corporation of America, Dean Gitter Productions and Theo Kamecke
results.brief_description: A record of the journey that culminated in man’s first step on the moon, covering the spectacular blastoff, the lunar landing and the return to earth. Effective use of music, sound effects and slow motion. Includes images taken from inside the lunar module.

results.title: Moonraker (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: Albert R. Broccoli, Danjaq, Lewis Gilbert and Ken Adam
results.brief_description: James Bond (Roger Moore) goes sci-fi in “Moonraker”, sourcing a missing space shuttle that has vanished in transit. A survey of the crash site reveals no evidence of the Moonraker; hijacking is the only explanation. Heading to California, Bond makes contact with billionaire Hugh Drax (Michael Lonsdale), head of Drax Industries and creator of the shuttle, as well NASA scientist and CIA Agent Dr Holly Goodhead (Lois Charles). Their paths cross again in Venice where Bond discovers a highly toxic nerve gas created from a rare orchid. The film culminates at a space station where a show down takes place with the megalomaniac Drax, intent on inflicting mass genocide and beginning a super race of perfect human specimens created in his image. Highlights include a centrifuge simulator, lethal Dobermans, a gondola chase, an out of control cable car and the return of the deadly steel-toothed killer, Jaws (Richard Kiel).

results.title: Moonchild
results.creator_credit: Anne Makepeace Productions and Anne Makepeace
results.brief_description: A dramatised re-enactment of the methods used by the Reverend Keith Moon’s Unification Church to brainwash young people into joining the church and carrying out its work. Actual ex-members of the group, who have now been deprogrammed, appear in the film as themselves, providing a frightening portrayal of their gradual conversion to the philosophy of the Moonies. Shows the deprogramming methods used by ex-Moonies on young people who still adhere to the beliefs of Keith Moon. An excellent insight into the power of group psychology, highlighting how vulnerable and aimless people can be easily controlled and exploited when removed from such support groups as family and friends. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Moonbird
results.brief_description: A colour cartoon of the fantasy of childhood. Two small boys, armed with rope, cage and bait, embark upon a night-time expedition to capture the nocturnal bird. A bird does finally appear. Making friends, the boys persuade the bird to go home with them. (Award: Venice)
